messages.message:
Just reading the docs and have come across 'Running in Memory' (https://aihub.instabase.com/docs/aihub/apis/apps-api/index.html#running-in-memory). From the limited info in the section I'm struggling to understand the implications of what this is used for. Can anyone provide some additional clarification/guidance?

What are the benefits to a user? What kind of situation might this be useful in?
hmm i think the “Running in memory” title is a little misleading

The “in-memory” way of running an app (i think we should rename this in the docs) is simpler than the “normal” way of running an app (https://aihub.instabase.com/docs/aihub/apis/apps-api/index.html#starting-a-new-ai-hub-app-run)

The “normal” way involves the following steps:
1. call the `/v2/zero-shot-idp/projects/app/run` endpoint, which will return a job id
2. call the `/v1/jobs/status` endpoint with the returned job id to check whether the app run is finished
3. call the `/v1/flow_binary/results` endpoint to get the app run results
The “in-memory” way involves only 1 step:
1. call the `/v2/zero-shot-idp/projects/app/{APP_ID}/run/sync` endpoint to run the app and get the results
cc @Wilson on potential improvements to the API docs

cc @tony.shi @Anil for run sync docs as well.  Additionally, you can specify the files and their contents in the request body directly, eliminating the need for you to upload files to the IB filesystem

All-in-all, It provides a much easier way to quickly use aihub apps via API
